['Administrator - A person responsible for managing or overseeing an organization, department, or team.', 'Manager - An individual who is in charge of directing and controlling employees within a company or institution to achieve specific goals.', 'Supervisor - A managerial position that involves supervising and coordinating the work of other employees to ensure tasks are completed effectively.', 'Director - The person responsible for overseeing and guiding various departments, projects or operations in an organization.', 'Coordinator - An individual who organizes and manages multiple aspects of a project, event or team to achieve specific objectives.', 'Executor - Someone assigned with executing the instructions and plans set out by higher authority, often responsible for implementing strategies and procedures in an organization.', 'Planner - A person responsible for organizing and managing long-term goals and projects within a company or institution.', 'Steward - An individual entrusted to manage and protect the resources of an organization, ensuring they are used effectively.', 'Operations Manager - A professional who oversees day-to-day activities in an organization with the aim of achieving optimal efficiency and effectiveness.', 'Human Resources Manager - An individual responsible for managing the entire human resources department within a company, including recruitment, training, performance evaluation, etc.', 'Project Manager - A professional who plans, organizes and manages projects in an organization to ensure completion of goals within allocated timeframes.', 'Facilities Manager - An individual responsible for overseeing the maintenance, upkeep, and management of physical spaces such as buildings, properties or campuses.', 'Quality Assurance Manager - A professional who ensures that all processes, products, and services are in line with predefined quality standards within an organization.', 'Supply Chain Manager - An individual responsible for managing the entire supply chain process, including procurement, production, distribution, and inventory management.', 'Financial Analyst - A professional who analyzes financial data to help companies make informed business decisions and manage their finances effectively.', "Risk Manager - An individual responsible for identifying, assessing, and mitigating potential risks that could impact the organization's operations or reputation.", 'Sales Manager - A professional responsible for leading a sales team to achieve specific revenue targets within an organization.', 'Strategic Planner - An individual who develops long-term plans, sets goals and objectives and coordinates efforts across various departments in order to drive growth and success.', "Operations Analyst - A professional responsible for analyzing data related to the company's operations, identifying areas for improvement and helping optimize processes and resources.", 'Program Manager - An individual responsible for managing a specific program within an organization, ensuring that it meets goals and objectives while staying on budget and schedule.']

['Oleander (Nerium oleander) - Known for its beautiful, vibrant pink or white clusters of flowers but contains cardiac glycosides which can be poisonous if ingested.', "Foxglove (Digitalis purpurea) - Although not a shrub, it's worth mentioning due to its similar yellow flower structure and high levels of digitalis alkaloids that are toxic when consumed.", 'Yew tree (Taxus baccata) – A coniferous tree rather than a shrub but famous for the poisonous berries produced alongside bright green leaves; some varieties have yellow-hued flowers in springtime.', "Poison Hemlock (Conium maculatum) - Not known primarily for yellow flowers, but its small white or purple ones are surrounded by sharp spiky foliage that's extremely toxic when ingested.", 'Wisteria (Wisteria floribunda) – While not typically poisonous and more famous for its fragrant lavender-blue flowers, certain species have yellow blooms in late spring or early summer', 'Rhododendron (Rhododendron spp.) – Contains numerous species with varying flower colors, including some that are yellow-flowered and can be poisonous due to their high alkaloid content when ingested in large quantities.', 'Buttercup (Ranunculus spp.) - Many Ranunculus species have bright yellow flowers but should not be consumed as they contain ranunculin, a compound that can cause severe skin irritation and gastrointestinal distress when ingested.', 'Foxglove spurge (Euphorbia lathyris) - This plant has bright yellow flowers but contains toxic latex known as euphorbialin, which causes dermatitis upon contact or if ingested.', 'Hellebore (Helleborus niger) – Known for its dark green leaves and usually purple-black flowers in the wild; however, some cultivated varieties may have yellowish blooms', 'Foxglove (Digitalis spp.) - This genus includes species with spurred or tubular flowers that can be various colors, including yellow shades; all are toxic due to cardiac glycosides.', 'Poison Ivy (Toxicodendron radicans) – Not primarily known for its flower color, but it does have tiny greenish-yellow clusters of flowers', 'English Yew (Taxus baccata ‘Fastigiate’) – A cultivar with unique yellow spurred flower clusters; however, the tree itself is not toxic', 'Helleborus niger variegatus - Varieties of hellebore can have green leaves speckled with white and may exhibit yellow flowers; they are toxic due to the presence of heliotrope, a group of glycoside compounds.', 'Lesser Celandine (Ficaria verna) – Known for its bright yellow umbellate clusters in spring but contains oxalates and protoanemonin that can irritate skin and mucous membranes when ingested or handled improperly.', "Indian Balsam (Impatiens glandulifera) - This invasive species has showy flowers, with some varieties featuring yellow petals; it's not toxic but can be harmful due to its vigorous growth and impact on native ecosystems.", "Witch Hazel (Hamamelis virginiana) – While the plant is known for its deep red or orange flowers, there are some cultivars with yellow-tinted petals; however, it's not particularly toxic.", 'Butterfly Weed (Asclepias tuberosa) - It boasts bright yellow flowers and contains compounds called cardenolides that can be harmful if ingested in significant amounts.', 'Tiger Lily (Lilium lancifolium) – Known for its large, showy blooms with distinctive orange-yellow markings but not typically classified as poisonous; however, some species have been known to cause allergic reactions upon contact or ingestion in rare cases.']
